text:
A reminder that $NVDA is hosting a power summit this week because AI data centers are projected to face a 44 gigawatt power shortfall by 2028.

‚Ä¢ At the top of the stack are the companies that create the power itself like nuclear fuel producers, turbines, backup generators & renewables from names like $CCJ, $LEU, $OKLO, $GEV, $FSLR & $UUUU that produce the raw power inputs the AI buildout depends on.
‚Ä¢ In the middle are the operators like $NEEM $VST, $TLN & $NRG who take those raw inputs & convert them into the dependable electricity that data centers rely on.
‚Ä¢ At the bottom of the stack are the companies that keep the grid stable, including long-duration storage & battery names like $TSLA, $EOSE, $QS, $MVST & $FLNC. 

All three layers now move together because AI data centers can only run at full capacity if fuel supply is secure, generation is steady & the grid can handle the load so if any part of that chain fails then utilization drops & even the strongest GPU demand curves break.

Power has become the real bottleneck of the AI economy & this summit exists because Nvidia knows the next trillion dollars of growth depends on solving it.

$NVDA just dropped its Nemotron 3 family of open models giving enterprises a plug-and-play blueprint for building agentic AI directly on Nvidia‚Äôs stack.

Jensen is expanding the software layer around the hardware so the entire ecosystem becomes dependent on Nvidia rather than just GPUs.

The S&P 100 in 2025 essentially separated into two groups: companies with real AI leverage outperformed and everything without it lagged.
 
Top performers:
1. $PLTR +146%
2. $AMD +74%
3. $GOOGL +63%
4. $AVGO +52%
5. $NVDA +31%

$GOOGL is testing a mobile real-estate ad unit that pulls live MLS listings through partner ComeHome.

It includes full details, filters and a ‚ÄúRequest a tour‚Äù button that routes buyers directly to top-rated agents.
$GOOGL signed a deal in Malaysia to source power from a 30 MW solar farm starting in 2027

$AMD is testing next-gen CPUs with Samsung Foundry at the 2nm level, exploring an alternative to $TSM for future chips.

Early prototypes are expected soon to see if Samsung‚Äôs process can meet AMD‚Äôs performance bar.

$ASTS BlueBird 6 has been fully encapsulated and handed off to the launcher, with the exact December liftoff date coming soon.

This mission kicks off a 2026 launch cadence of roughly 1 launch every 45 days.

$EOSE is my favorite name in this space because it sits at the exact fault line of the AI power problem that almost no one is pricing correctly yet. 

AI data centers create violent load swings that break grids and long-duration storage sits directly at that bottleneck.

$PLTR could give $HIMS a unified intelligence layer that turns its fragmented data into a real acquisition and retention engine. 

If Hims ever wants to be valued like a $50B healthcare platform then this is the kind of system that gets them there.

$NOW acquires Armis for ~$7B (its largest deal ever) adding device-level cyber security across IoT, medical & industrial endpoints.

Armis has scaled ARR from $200M to $300M in under year which gives ServiceNow a native cyber visibility layer that fits directly into its enterprise workflow platform.

THE 3 FIXES $HIMS NEEDS RIGHT NOW

1. Fix the top of the funnel so new customers start growing again  

Hims built its whole business on being able to bring in huge numbers of new customers cheaply and easily. That stopped working when marketing got more expensive and net new subscribers slowed. Even though Hims has more than 2.5M subscribers today, the engine isn't adding people fast enough unless the company leans harder on raising ARPU.

I also don‚Äôt buy the idea that this is ONLY a Sexual Health issue shifting from episodic to subscription SKUs. The broader truth is that digital ads are more expensive, more crowded and harder to win now that companies like $AMZN & $GOOGL are competing for the same customers.

The fastest way to reset sentiment is to stabilize CAC, and Hims can do that by publishing more transparent funnel metrics and shifting ~25% of marketing spend into high-intent, low-CAC channels that actually scale. Even one or two quarters where CAC flattens would flip the narrative because it proves the engine can still scale efficiently.

2. Make Diagnostics the default onboarding path

Diagnostics can change the business because it gives Hims a way to guide every new user into the correct treatment path instead of hoping they arrive through a single-category entry point like hair loss or sexual health. If diagnostics becomes the front door then someone might come in for one issue but stay for multiple conditions over time.

That increases retention, raises lifetime value and stabilizes revenue. For this to work Hims needs to route all new users into a single diagnostic intake, build a recommendation engine that automatically matches users to the right care categories and follow up with personalized plans that raise ARPU naturally instead of relying on blunt upsells.

3. How Palantir‚Äôs ontology would help Hims fix acquisition

Hims has one of the richest data sets in consumer healthcare. They already know how different conditions convert, how long users stay on treatments, what causes churn, when people switch categories and what long-term health journeys look like. The problem is that this data lives in separate systems and teams, which means they see pieces of the puzzle but not the whole picture.

This is exactly the kind of problem $PLTR ontology is built to solve and if I were @AndrewDudum this would be one of my highest-priority initiatives. 

Palantir‚Äôs ontology acts like an organizational brain that connects data from every corner of the company and shows how everything fits together in real time. It would let Hims see the entire customer journey as one unified system from the moment someone clicks a TikTok ad, to their first prescription, to refill behavior, to switching into new categories and long-term retention.

Right now Hims sees each part of the customer journey in isolation but Palantir would let them stitch it into one living system that updates in real time and actually explains why cohorts behave the way they do.
